qas.question: What is the technique that analyzes the constituent bonds of molecules to identify them?
What happens to a molecule if an oscillation results in a dipole being changed?

answers.text: it will absorb a photon that has the same frequency

qas.question: What do the vibrational frequencies of molecules usually correspond to?
What is the term for light radiation in the 4000–400 cm−1 spectrum?
What technique can be used to identify organic compounds by analysis of their constituent bonds?
A group of chemical bonds in a molecule may have how many modes of oscillation?
What do most vibrations correspond to the frequencies of?

plausible_answers.text: the stretching and bending motions of the group as a whole.

qas.question: What are multiple modes of oscillation in a spectrum caused by?
What is the amount of absorption a group of atoms will show in cm?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Infrared vibrational spectroscopy<b4_0/><a0_0/> (see also near-infrared spectroscopy) is a technique that can be used to identify molecules by analysis of their constituent bonds. Each chemical bond in a molecule vibrates at a frequency characteristic of that bond. A group of atoms in a molecule (e.g., CH2) may have <b5_0>multiple<b5_0/> modes of oscillation caused by <b7_0>the stretching and bending motions of the group as a whole.<b7_0/> If an oscillation leads to a change in dipole in the molecule then <a1_0>it will absorb a photon that has the same frequency<a1_0/>. The vibrational frequencies of most molecules correspond to <a2_0>the frequencies of <b6_0>infrared light<b6_0/><a2_0/>. Typically, the technique is used to study organic compounds using light radiation from 4000–400 cm−1, <a3_0>the mid-infrared<a3_0/>. A spectrum of all the frequencies of absorption in a sample is recorded. This can be used to gain information about the sample composition in terms of chemical groups present and also its purity (for example, a wet sample will show a broad O-H absorption around <b8_0>3200 cm−1<b8_0/>).
